Chapter 6: The Two Truths (6)
At that time, the World-Honored One again told the Bodhisattva MahÄsattva Who Subdues All Obstacles:
Good man!
Bodhisattva MahÄsattvas who possess ten qualities well understand the conventional truth.
What are the ten?
Namely, provisionally speaking of form, not the ultimate truth, thus attaining the dharma of form without attachment;
provisionally speaking of feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness, not the ultimate truth, thus attaining consciousness without attachment;
provisionally speaking of the earth element, not the ultimate truth, thus attaining the earth element without attachment;
provisionally speaking of the water, fire, wind, space, and consciousness elements, not the ultimate truth, thus attaining these elements without attachment;
Although they attain the eye faculty, they do not cling to it;
Although they attain the ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind faculties, they do not cling to them;
Although they attain a self, they do not cling to it;
Although they attain sentient beings, they do not cling to them;
Although they attain life, person, nourisher, one who is nourished, human, and so forth, they do not cling to them;ğŸ”½Although they attain the world, they do not cling to it;
Although they attain worldly dharmas, they do not cling to them;
Although they attain the Buddha Dharma, they do not cling to it;
It is only provisionally called enlightenment, not the ultimate truth. Although attaining enlightenment, one does not cling to the one who attains enlightenment.
Good sons!
Provisional names, words, and phrases, and conceptualization are called conventional truth, and within worldly dharmas there is no ultimate truth.
However, if one departs from worldly dharmas, the ultimate truth cannot be spoken of.
Good sons!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas skillfully understand conventional truth within these dharmas, but are not said to understand ultimate truth.
Good sons!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who possess these ten dharmas skillfully understand conventional truth.
Good sons!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who possess ten dharmas skillfully understand ultimate truth.
What are the ten?

Namely, possessing the Dharma of non-arising, possessing the Dharma of non-cessation, possessing the indestructible Dharma, possessing the Dharma of neither increase nor decrease, neither coming out nor entering, possessing the Dharma of leaving the realm of objects, possessing the Dharma of no words, possessing the Dharma of no disputes, possessing the Dharma of no false names, possessing the tranquil Dharma, possessing the Dharma of the sages.
Why is it so?
Good man!

The ultimate truth is neither arising nor ceasing, neither decaying nor disintegrating, neither increasing nor decreasing. It cannot be spoken or explained by written words or phrases. It transcends disputes.
Good man!
The ultimate truth is without words or speech. Its inherent nature is pure. All sages realize it within themselves.
Whether the Buddha appears in the world or not, the nature of dharmas is always thus, neither decreasing nor increasing.
Good man!

For the sake of this Dharma, all bodhisattvas shave their heads and beards, put on dyed robes, and with a good mind, leave their relatives and go to secluded places to leave the household life and cultivate the Way. They diligently endure suffering as if burning their heads, only seeking to attain this wonderful Dharma.
Good man!
If there were no such ultimate truth, the cultivation of pure conduct would all be useless, and the Buddha's appearance in the world would also be useless.
Good man!
Therefore, you should know that there is ultimate truth.
Because there is ultimate truth, it is said that all bodhisattvas understand ultimate truth.
Good man!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who possess these ten qualities well understand ultimate truth.
Good man!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who possess ten qualities well understand the twelve links of dependent arising.
What are the ten?

Namely, all dharmas are empty and unreal, fragile and perishable, like the moon in the water, like a reflection in a mirror, like an echo in a valley, like a dream, like an illusion, not remaining for a moment, shaking and unstable, arising in dependence on conditions, all of which are fully known.
Contemplating in this way:
'All these dharmas are empty and unreal, so fragile and perishable, up to arising in dependence on conditions, seeing arising and ceasing.'
He further contemplates:
'What are the causes and conditions for the arising of these dharmas?
What are the causes and conditions for the ceasing of these dharmas?'

Having contemplated in this way, he then knows that ignorance is the cause and condition for the arising of these dharmas. What is produced by ignorance, the source of ignorance, the root of ignorance, in dependence on ignorance, the dharmas of formations arise;
Formations are the condition for consciousness, and in dependence on consciousness, name-and-form is provisionally spoken of;
When name-and-form is established, the six sense bases are spoken of;
Because of the six sense bases, contact can arise;
Because of contact, the three kinds of feelings arise;
Because of feelings, infants and ordinary beings give rise to the suffering of craving;
Because of craving, one grasps the four kinds of grasping;
Because of the four kinds of grasping, there is continuation, and because of continuation, birth;
Because of birth, old age, death, sorrow, lamentation, suffering, and distress all arise, and a mass of pure suffering comes together.
For this reason, the wise and intelligent should diligently seek to extinguish this ignorance, to break through ignorance, to uproot ignorance so that it does not arise again.
Because of the extinction of ignorance, all dharmas that are caused by ignorance are extinguished without remainder.
Just as when the life faculty is extinguished, all the faculties perish together;
When ignorance is extinguished, all dharmas that depend on ignorance are extinguished together.
Because of the extinction of ignorance, afflictions do not arise;
Because there are no afflictions, one is not born in the six destinies.
Why is this?
Because the causes and conditions of birth and death have already been extinguished, one is therefore able to attain the great nirvÄá¹‡a, which is permanent, blissful, self, and pure.
Good sons!
In this way, bodhisattvas who possess ten qualities well understand the twelve links of dependent arising.
Good sons!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who possess ten qualities understand their own bodies.
What are the ten?
Good sons!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas contemplate in this way:
'In this life of mine, what kind of family am I born into?
Am I born into a brahmin family?ğŸ”½Am I born into a ká¹£atriya family?
Am I born into a wealthy householder's family?ğŸ”½Am I born into a lowly family?
Am I born into an inferior family?'
If one is born into a noble and wealthy family, one should not be arrogant or conceited because of this;
if one is born into a humble and poor family, one should think like this:
'I planted this karma in my past lives, which has led to such a poor and destitute karmic retribution.'
For this reason, I cultivate renunciation extensively.
Because of cultivating renunciation, I happily seek to leave the household life.
After leaving the household life, I contemplate like this:
'What is the purpose of my leaving the household life now?'
I then know that by leaving the household life and liberating myself, I can liberate others. For this reason, I should not be lazy or indolent.
Having contemplated like this,
'Now that I have left the household life, what unwholesome things have not yet been extinguished?
If I extinguish this dharma, I will give rise to joy.'
For this reason, I vigorously strive to extinguish this dharma.
I further contemplate like this:
'What wholesome dharmas can I make increase?
Because of their increase, I will give rise to joy.'
For the sake of increasing wholesome dharmas, I vigorously strive.
I further contemplate like this:
'Based on which teachers can all wholesome dharmas increase and all unwholesome ones be extinguished?'
For this reason, whether the teacher is learned or not, whether he observes the precepts or not, always give rise to the thought of respect, just as you would for the buddhas.
With utmost sincerity, serve and respect the preceptor and ÄcÄrya in the same way, thinking like this:

'Relying on the power of the teacher, the wholesome practices that have not yet been fulfilled will be able to be completed, and afflictions that have not yet been extinguished will be able to be extinguished.'

Toward these people, give rise to the thought of a preceptor, serve with utmost sincerity, and give rise to great joy. In wholesome dharmas, cultivate and practice in accordance with them, and in unwholesome dharmas, go against them and practice.
Furthermore, think like this:
'Who is my teacher?'
Contemplate in this way and you will know:
'My teacher is omniscient, teaches all dharmas, has compassion for the world, has great kindness and compassion, is a great field of merit, and is a teacher of gods and humans.
' For these reasons, you should give rise to joy, and further think like this:
'How fortunate, how fortunate!
I have now attained the supreme benefit. I am able to show me the correct Dharma to study and practice. Even if I lose my life, I dare not violate the Dharma I have received.
If I am able to not violate it, then this is making offerings to the buddhas, the tathÄgatas, and practicing in accordance with them.'
He further thinks like this:
'Whose food and drink offerings do I now receive?'
Whether from wealthy families or poor families, let these food and drink offerings give rise to great fruits and benefits, and I will receive these food and drink offerings.
He further thinks like this:
'What kind of mind do these donors, whether poor or wealthy, have when making offerings to me and providing food and drink?'
In this way, I know:

'These donors now think of us as renunciant people, practicing the Dharma of ascetics, thinking of us as a field of merit, thinking of us as upholding precepts, thinking of us as giving rise to goodness, thinking of us as extinguishing evil.
Therefore, I now do not go against their minds, upholding the precepts, virtues, and meritorious deeds of the renunciant life, the field of merit.'
And think like this:

'I should deliver all beings from beginningless birth and death. Now I have attained renunciation, entered the path, and practiced the Dharma of ascetics, which is my first deliverance from birth and death;
I should cultivate the virtues of ascetics, which is the second time I cross birth and death.
I am now courageous and dare not be lazy, only for the sake of attaining this pure Dharma.'
In this way, I should deliver those who have been in birth and death without beginning or end.
Good sons!
In this way, a bodhisattva who makes such observations will know his own body.
Good sons!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who possess ten qualities understand the world.
What are the ten?

Namely, towards the arrogant and resentful, one gives rise to humility; towards the proud and haughty, one gives rise to respect; towards the deceitful and cunning, one acts with sincerity and honesty; towards the liars, one cultivates truthful speech; towards the abusive, one speaks loving words; towards the coarse and strong, one is naturally gentle and yielding; towards the venomous and poisonous, one cultivates much patience and forbearance; towards the wicked and untrustworthy, one cultivates much loving-kindness; towards the suffering and distressed, one cultivates much compassion; towards the stingy and miserly, one cultivates much joy and giving.

Namely, the precepts are pure, without gaps, without mixture, without flaws, and without blemishes;

Courageously and diligently, not slacking off even for a moment;
Endowed with meditative concentration, the mind is not scattered;
Comprehending the distinctions of much learning, not practicing wrong doctrines;
Endowed with sharp wisdom, not giving rise to dull faculties;
Naturally compassionate, not habituated to anger.
Bodhisattva Subduer of All Obstacles said:
World-Honored One!

If they do not possess them all, can they still be born there?
The Buddha said:
Good man!
If one of these ten dharmas is fully possessed, without gaps or mixtures, without flaws or blemishes, pure and clear, all dharmas will be fully possessed.
Why is this so?
Possessing the ten dharmas leads to rebirth in the Pure Land, not by not possessing them.

Thus, bodhisattvas, possessing ten dharmas, are born in the Pure Land of buddhas.

Because of their profound mind.

Thus, bodhisattvas who possess these ten qualities do not undergo birth from a womb;

Namely, being without attachment;

In accordance with the Buddha's true teachings, one practices and follows them;
Striving with vigor, one skillfully learns contentment;
Clothing, food and drink, bedding, and medicine as appropriate;

Always giving rise to fear towards all objects of the senses;

In this way, bodhisattvas, endowed with ten dharmas, leave the home-life.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, endowed with ten dharmas, purify their livelihood.

They are: being far removed from arrogance, flattery, and gain, being far removed from appearances, being far removed from flattery, not seeking wealth unjustly, being free from wealth that is contrary to the Dharma, being free from impure wealth, not being attached to wealth, not being defiled by gain, not being thirsty and craving, and being content with wealth that accords with the Dharma.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, for the sake of material gain, do not speak slowly and softly, nor do they speak affectionately or in a way that accords with others. They are far removed from all of these kinds of arrogance with the mouth.

This is called harboring heat within, namely, outwardly claiming to be without greed while the mind actually desires to obtain.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, when seeing donors, do not show that their robes and bowls are in disrepair or that they lack medicine, but reveal their deficiencies and seek donations without speaking.

'Such-and-such donor gave me this thing, and I repay their generosity with kindness and virtue.'
They do not say this:
'Cause the previous donor to know that I uphold the precepts, know that I have much learning, know that I have few desires, and that I accept their donations with kindness and compassion.'
They do not use flattery to stir things up.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas do not create physical or mental wounds in seeking wealth and goods.

As for the wounds of the body, for the sake of wealth and goods, one does not avoid hard work, one's body is engaged in all directions, one is hurried and busy, and one goes against the precepts and rules.
As for the wounds of the mind, one gives rise to much jealousy towards fellow students who have less in terms of offerings and support.
How do bodhisattvas avoid wealth that is contrary to the Dharma?
They do not deceive others with light weights and small measures, and they do not seek wealth and goods through deceitful friendships or other deceptions.
How do bodhisattvas avoid impure wealth?
Bodhisattvas, if it is not given, or if they do not rejoice in it, they do not use anything related to the property of stupas, the property of the Dharma, or the property of the Saá¹…gha.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, if they obtain wealth and goods, do not think of them as their own, do not think of them as wealth, and do not hoard them. At the appropriate time, they give them away to those who have given to them in the past, to their parents and relatives, and to their various kinsmen, and at the appropriate time they use them themselves.
When obtaining this wealth, one should not give rise to attachment;
When not obtaining wealth, one should not be agitated or thirsty for it, and should not give rise to an evil mind or take faults with the donor.

One should obtain wealth in accordance with the Dharma, and share it with the assembly. It is praised by the Buddha, not criticized by bodhisattvas and great beings, extolled by celestial spirits, and joyfully received by fellow students. One should abide in contentment with this wealth.
Good man, in this way, bodhisattvas, with these ten qualities complete, purify their livelihood and sustain themselves.

Beneficial giving refers to the giving of the Dharma;

Good man!

Good man!
